J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Yes, but not the kind of idea you wanted. Maybe you already know this, 
> but I'll share it anyway, in case it helps. I strongly recommend your 
> students start with at least a small amount of already test-driven code. 
> Especially in shorter formats (1/2 day or less), starting with a blank 
> slate tends to be onerous.

I ended up starting with the Apache Commons Lang Fraction class. That 
proved to be easy enough to test, simple enough for everyone to 
understand, and yet have a few juicy bugs for students to find. Notes here:

http://www.cafeaulait.org/slides/starwest/junit/JUnit__A_Hands-On_Introduction_for_Testers.html

The fraction class would probably also make a nice example for a more 
classic test driven class. In the past I've used complex numbers 
instead, but fractions are a little more widely understood.

--
